articles.title: 'We're a Fortress Now': The Militarization of US Elections Is Here
articles.description: From bulletproof glass, drones, and snipers to boulders blocking election offices, the US democratic system is bracing for violent attacks in 2024.
articles.content: Drones, snipers, razor wire, sniffer dogs, body armor, bulletproof glass, and 24-hour armed security. This is not a list of protections in place for a visit by the president of the United States nor the contents of a shipment to frontline troops fighting in Ukraine. This is a list of the security measures election officials in counties across the US have had to implement ahead of Tuesday‚Äôs vote as a result of the unprecedented threats they have faced in recent years. Officials are putting in place the typical final measures to ensure the smooth operation of an election, but beyond checking that they have enough ballots and that machines are working properly, officials are now faced with having to monitor for threats and make sure they have done everything they can to protect themselves and their staff. ‚ÄúGiven the current political environment, the possibility that an event may occur has increased, and our election professionals have responded in kind,‚Äù says Tammy Patrick, a former election official in Arizona‚Äôs Maricopa County who is now a senior adviser at the nonprofit Bolstering Elections Initiative. ‚ÄúEfforts focusing on the physical security of the voters, election workers, and staff by putting in bulletproof glass, panic buttons, razor wire, and fencing are fairly common, as is the installation of surveillance cameras and systems, cyber protections, and training on de-escalation techniques and response drills.‚Äù Nowhere in the US is the militarization of the election process more evident than in Maricopa County. The fourth largest county in the nation, Maricopa became ground zero for election denial conspiracists in recent years, after GOP lawmakers sanctioned a bogus recount in 2021, run by the Florida company Cyber Ninjas. As a result, the county has for years been putting increased security measures in place. ‚ÄúWe're a fortress now,‚Äù Stephen Richer, the Maricopa County Recorder, told WIRED back in February, outlining how he had to navigate security fencing, metal detectors, and security checks in order to get into his office. As the 2024 election approaches, the measures Maricopa officials are putting in place have been ratcheted up significantly. Officials have added a second layer of security fencing to protect election offices, as well as concrete k-rails, which means election workers will be bused in from offsite locations due to reduced parking spaces. At the country‚Äôs tabulation center, every door will be fitted with metal detectors, floodlights will be installed, and on election day the center will be protected by a ring of snipers deployed on roofs around the building, election officials told NBC. There will also be mounted police on standby outside the building, round-the-clock armed security, and drones in flight over the building, monitoring for approaching threats. The entire election office building is also covered in security cameras that livestream everything online for anyone to watch, a security measure that doubles as a way of offering transparency into its election process. ‚ÄúThe security and safety of our elections and those that help conduct them are paramount in ensuring a smooth election process,‚Äù Taylor Kinnerup, communications director for the Maricopa County Recorder‚Äôs Office, tells WIRED. ‚ÄúSince January of 2021, our office has increased badge security access, installed permanent barriers, and added additional cybersecurity measures based on the recommendations of law enforcement and other experts.‚Äù The threats against election workers spiked in the wake of the 2020 election, spurred on by Donald Trump‚Äôs baseless allegations that the election was stolen. While the threats receded somewhat in between election cycles, they have picked up again in recent months. WIRED revealed earlier this month that the Department of Homeland Security has issued a series of reports to government agencies warning about the ‚Äúheightened risk‚Äù of right-wing extremists carrying out attacks around the election. Just last week, the Justice Department‚Äôs Election Threats Task Force announced charges against four men for threats they made against election officials. ‚ÄúThe fact that election workers need to be worried about their security is incomprehensible and unacceptable,‚Äù FBI director Chris Wray said in a statement about the threats. Some of the charges relate to threats made back in 2022; as a result, election officials have been preparing for years for next week‚Äôs vote. Since the beginning of last year, the US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency has conducted over 1,000 voluntary physical security assessments at election offices. One of these assessments was conducted in Pennsylvania‚Äôs Luzerne County in late August, with officials from CISA and Homeland Security recommending that barriers be installed to prevent cars from ramming into the ground floor of the building housing the county‚Äôs election offices in Wilkes Barre. ‚ÄúThis is a measure taken to safeguard staff, the public, and the ballots,‚Äù Luzerne County manager Romilda Crocamo told local TV station WVIA earlier this month as workers installed boulders along the front of the building. Crocamo also said the county had decided against using drop boxes because they could not adequately protect them. This week, multiple drop boxes in Portland, Oregon, and Vancouver, Washington, were set on fire in incidents police say were linked. In addition to protecting the buildings where election staff work, some high-profile election officials have had to protect themselves. Arizona secretary of state Adrian Fontes, the top election official in his state, revealed on Monday that he regularly wears a bulletproof vest after a series of threats were posted online and included his home address. In Adams County, Colorado, the county clerk and recorder Josh Zygielbaum has also been advised by local police to wear body armor after someone followed him home after a recent local election. Zygielbaum recently told USA Today that he has taken the advice and now wears one every day. He has previously used militaristic phrases like ‚Äúharden the office as a target‚Äù to describe his efforts to beef up security, which has included the installation of panic buttons under every desk Tate Fall, Cobb County, Georgia‚Äôs election director, has also installed panic buttons that link directly to emergency services after a poll worker reported an agitated voter during this year‚Äôs presidential primary who was carrying a gun. In some cases, new election offices have been built since the last election, including ones in California‚Äôs Los Angeles County and Durham County, North Carolina. These have been built with security in mind and feature bulletproof glass, security cameras, and doors that will open only with the right credentials. In Los Angeles County, they are also deploying trained sniffer dogs to screen all the mail coming into election offices after a surge in letters sent to officials containing white powder, several of which have tested positive for fentanyl, a powerful synthetic opioid that can be deadly even in small doses. As a result, most election offices across the country have Narcan kits on hand, and officials have been trained on how to administer the drug in the case of an accidental opioid overdose. Taking things a step further, in Durham County‚Äôs new election office, they have constructed a dedicated mail-sorting room that features a separate exhaust system to prevent potentially hazardous substances contaminating the rest of the office. ‚ÄúElection workers now need to be experts in security, cybersecurity, public health, and public relations, while handling drastically more information requests and recounts,‚Äù Adam Hinds, former Massachusetts state senator and current CEO of the nonprofit Edward M. Kennedy Institute, tells WIRED. ‚ÄúOne problem is they are already stretched in terms of funding and resources. As election administration receives more attention, our election workers deserve the resources necessary.‚Äù In your inbox: A new series of tips for how to use AI every day Meet the masked vigilante tracking down billions in crypto scams Deep dive: This app set out to fight pesticides. articles.author: Angela Watercutter
articles.title: Forget Screen Time. We Need to Talk About Screen Real Estate
articles.description: Spending many hours daily looking at screens feels like a foregone conclusion. The new challenge is paring down what fills them.
articles.content: ‚ÄúFor those of you who want Election Night to feel even more unhinged, I highly recommend elections.omg.lol.‚Äù That's WIRED senior editor Andrew Couts talking about a single-serving site with a three-by-three grid of nine YouTube embeds, each broadcasting a 24-hour news channel‚Äôs live coverage. Election.omg.lol‚Äôs nine portals into the future of America provided a constant stream of red-and-blue maps, talking heads, and man-on-the-street reports. It was nauseating, ‚Äúhorrifying and kinda helpful,‚Äù and ‚Äúa hell site.‚Äù It was also one of four screens I was looking at the moment I clicked on it. Yes, on election night 2024, like so many others, I had CNN on, a laptop open, and a phone in my hand. This is not new; lots of people watch TV with a second device nearby. What became clear as the results started pouring in was how much space on each of those screens was devoted to some smaller, use-specific screen. CNN, of course, had chyrons full of headlines and tickers showing how many Electoral College votes Donald Trump and Vice President Kamala Harris had. There were also boxes blaring countdowns for when the next polls would close. My iPhone contained a revolving door of TikTok, X, and Instagram. (I saved myself a small piece of virtual estate by not turning on the Dynamic Island election results service Apple unveiled this week.) My laptop, a combination of Chrome tabs open to news sites and a Slack full of chats with coworkers‚Äîwhich is how I got served that Verge post in the first place. No one does picture-in-picture on their TV screens anymore, really, but TVs have been supplemented with tablets, smartphones, laptops. Nearly every screen available to us, is now full of other screens, bifurcating into oblivion. Even in VRChat, where my colleague Boone Ashworth spent much of his election eve, there were people looking at screens ‚Ä¶ embedded into the screens strapped to their faces. Not to be all Andy Rooney about it, but maybe that‚Äôs too much. Not that I want to go back to the days of just watching one thing on TV or reading one book, absent other things to distract me, but perhaps it‚Äôs time we started treating the space on screens like it holds actual value. This column is named The Monitor because it‚Äôs about the things we watch, device agnostic, but it‚Äôs also about what we pay attention to, what we observe. Maybe reducing the number of things one pays attention to provides a way to observe more. The Monitor is a weekly column devoted to everything happening in the WIRED world of culture, from movies to memes, TV to TikTok. Or, perhaps, eliminating one screen entirely is the answer. Fewer and fewer people watch TV on TVs, and according to Nielsen viewership for the presidential election was down more than 25 percent this year. More than 42 million people watched across TV networks on Tuesday. Back in 2020, that number was nearly 57 million. Covid-19 likely had more people glued to their TVs in 2020, but this election still saw a marked decrease over previous elections. Another fun stat from this week? Online doctors‚Äô appointment app Zocdoc reports mental health bookings shot up 22 percent between 6 am and 8 am on Wednesday after the election was called for Trump. Maybe people are looking for a different kind of face time. ‚ÄúThe Most Mysterious Song on the Internet‚Äù has been found. It‚Äôs called ‚ÄúSubways of Your Mind‚Äù by FEX. It took nearly 17 years and a bunch of dedicated Redditors to uncover it. It‚Äôs been a long week. Here‚Äôs Kyle MacLachlan dancing in a hot dog suit. Moo Deng accurately predicted the outcome of the US presidential election. But mostly she was just hungry. articles.author: Tess Owen
articles.title: Leaked Docs From Far-Right Militias Show History of Voter Intimidation Plans
articles.description: ‚ÄúAll the state leaders should be getting their people out ‚Ä¶ to watch for ballot stuffing,‚Äù wrote the leader of the American Patriots Three Percent militia. ‚ÄúOur nation depends on this."
articles.content: A trove of leaked internal messages and documents from the militia American Patriots Three Percent‚Äîalso known as AP3‚Äîreveals how the group coordinated with election denial groups as part of a plan to conduct paramilitary surveillance of ballot boxes during the midterm elections in 2022. This information was leaked to Distributed Denial of Secrets (DDoSecrets), a nonprofit that says it publishes hacked and leaked documents in the public interest. The person behind these AP3 leaks is an individual who, according to their statement uploaded by DDoSecrets, infiltrated the militia and grew so alarmed by what they were seeing that they felt compelled to go public with the information ahead of the upcoming presidential election. Election and federal officials have already voiced concern about possible voter intimidation this November, in part due to the proliferation of politically violent rhetoric and election denialism. Some right-wing groups have already committed to conducting surveillance of ballot boxes remotely using AI-driven cameras. And last month, a Homeland Security bulletin warned that domestic extremist groups could plan on sabotaging election infrastructure including ballot drop boxes. Devin Burghart, president and executive director of the Institute for Research and Education on Human Rights, says that AP3‚Äôs leaked plans for the 2022 midterms should be a warning for what may transpire next month. ‚ÄúBaseless election denial conspiracies stoking armed militia surveillance of ballot drop boxes is a dangerous form of voter intimidation,‚Äù Burghart tells WIRED. ‚ÄúThe expansion of the election denial, increased militia activity, and growing coordination between them, is cause for serious concern heading into November. Now with voter suppression groups like True the Vote and some GOP elected officials targeting drop boxes for vigilante activity, the situation should be raising alarms.‚Äù The leaked messages from 2022 show how AP3 and other militias provided paramilitary heft to ballot box monitoring operations organized by ‚ÄúThe People‚Äôs Movement,‚Äù the group that spearheaded the 2021 anti-vaccine convoy protest, and Clean Elections USA, a group with links to the team behind the 2000 Mules film that falsely claimed widespread voter fraud. In the leaked chats, People‚Äôs Movement leader Carolyn Smith identifies herself as an honorary AP3 member. AP3 is run by Scot Seddon, a former Army Reservist, Long Islander, and male model, according to a ProPublica profile on him published in August. That profile, which relied on the same anonymous infiltrator who leaked AP3‚Äôs internal messages to DDoSecrets, explains that AP3 escaped scrutiny in the aftermath of January 6 in part because Seddon, after spending weeks preparing his ranks to go to DC, ultimately decided to save his soldiers for another day. ProPublica reported that some members went anyway but were under strict instruction to forgo any AP3 insignia. According to the leaked messages, Seddon also directed his state leaders to participate in the ‚Äúoperation.‚Äù ‚ÄúAll of us have a vested interest in this nation,‚Äù Seddon said in a leaked video. ‚ÄúSo all the state leaders should be getting their people out and manning and observing ballot boxes, to watch for ballot stuffing. This is priority. This goes against getting your double cheeseburger at mcdonalds ‚Ä¶ Our nation depends on this. Our future depends on this. This ain't no bullshit issue. We need to be tight on this, straight up.‚Äù A flier using militaristic language shared across various state-specific Telegram channels lays out how this operation would work. With ‚ÄúRules of Engagement‚Äù instructions, ‚ÄúVolunteers‚Äù are told not to interfere with anyone dropping off their ballots. If someone is suspected of dropping off ‚Äúmultiple ballots,‚Äù then observers are told to record the event, and make a note of the individual's appearance and their vehicle's license plate number. In the event of any sort of confrontation, they‚Äôre supposed to ‚Äúreport as soon as possible to your area Captain.‚Äù ‚ÄúAt the end of each shift, Patriots will prepare a brief report of activity and transmit it to [the ballot] box team Captain promptly,‚Äù the flier states. The person who leaked these documents and messages says that these paramilitary observers masquerading as civilians will often have a QRF‚Äîquick reaction force‚Äîon standby who can ‚Äústage an armed response‚Äù should a threat or confrontation arise. The goal of the ‚Äúoperation,‚Äù according to that flier, was to ‚ÄúStop the Mules.‚Äù ‚ÄúThese are the individuals stuffing ballot boxes,‚Äù the flier says. ‚ÄúThey are well trained and financed. There is a global network backing them up. They pick up fake ballots from phony non-profits and deliver them to ballot boxes, usually between 2400 hours and 0600 hours.‚Äù (This was the core conspiracy of 2,000 Mules; the conservative media company behind the film has since issued an apology for promoting election conspiracies and committed to halting its distribution). Fears about widespread armed voter intimidation during the 2022 midterms‚Äîstemming from online chatter and warnings from federal agencies‚Äînever materialized in full. However, there were scattered instances of people showing up to observe ballot drops in Arizona. These individuals, according to the statement by the anonymous leaker in the DDoSecrets files, were not ‚Äúlone wolves‚Äù‚Äîthey were part of ‚Äúhighly organized groups who intended to influence the elections through intimidation.‚Äù In one widely-publicized incident, two clearly armed people wearing balaclavas and tactical gear showed up in Mesa, Arizona, to conduct drop box surveillance. They were never identified, though a Telegram video on DDoSecrets shows AP3‚Äôs North Carolina chapter head Burley Ross admitting that one of them was part of his unit. Ross says that the individual was Elias Humiston, who had previously been conducting vigilante border surveillance. ‚ÄúI was well aware they were doing drop box observations,‚Äù said Ross. ‚ÄúI was not aware they were doing so in full kit.‚Äù Ross added that Humiston had since resigned from the group. Seddon also addressed the ‚Äúlittle incident in Arizona,‚Äù stressing the importance of maintaining clean optics to avoid scrutiny. ‚ÄúWe had pushed for helping to maintain election integrity through monitoring the ballot boxes,‚Äù said Seddon, in a video message on Telegram. ‚ÄúWe never told anyone to do it like that.‚Äù The militia movement largely retreated from public view in the aftermath of the January 6 riot at the US Capitol in 2021. The high-profile implication of the Oath Keepers in the riot, which at the time was America‚Äôs biggest militia, thrust the broader militia movement into the spotlight. Amid intense scrutiny, stigma, and creeping paranoia about federal informants, some militias rebanded or even disbanded. But as WIRED reporting has shown, after a brief lull in activity, the militia movement has been quietly rebuilding, reorganizing, and recruiting. With AP3 at its helm, it‚Äôs also been engaging in armed training. Election conspiracies have only continued to fester since 2022, and AP3 has been aggressively recruiting and organizing. Moreover, the rhetoric in the group has also intensified. ‚ÄúThe next election won‚Äôt be decided at a Ballot Box,‚Äù wrote an AP3 leader earlier this year in a private chat, according to ProPublica. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôll be decided at the ammo box.‚Äù ‚ÄúEvery American has a right to go to the ballot box without fear and the authorities need to urgently learn the lessons of 2022‚Äîand the lessons contained in these documents‚Äîso they can prevent something even worse from happening in the coming weeks,‚Äù the infiltrator wrote in the DDoS statement. articles.author: Eric Geller
articles.title: How a Trump Win Could Unleash Dangerous AI
articles.description: Donald Trump's opposition to ‚Äúwoke‚Äù safety standards for artificial intelligence would likely mean the dismantling of regulations that protect Americans from misinformation, discrimination, and worse.
articles.content: If Donald Trump wins the US presidential election in November, the guardrails could come off of artificial intelligence development, even as the dangers of defective AI models grow increasingly serious. Trump‚Äôs election to a second term would dramatically reshape‚Äîand possibly cripple‚Äîefforts to protect Americans from the many dangers of poorly designed artificial intelligence, including misinformation, discrimination, and the poisoning of algorithms used in technology like autonomous vehicles. The federal government has begun overseeing and advising AI companies under an executive order that President Joe Biden issued in October 2023. But Trump has vowed to repeal that order, with the Republican Party platform saying it ‚Äúhinders AI innovation‚Äù and ‚Äúimposes Radical Leftwing ideas‚Äù on AI development. Trump‚Äôs promise has thrilled critics of the executive order who see it as illegal, dangerous, and an impediment to America‚Äôs digital arms race with China. Those critics include many of Trump‚Äôs closest allies, from X CEO Elon Musk and venture capitalist Marc Andreessen to Republican members of Congress and nearly two dozen GOP state attorneys general. Trump‚Äôs running mate, Ohio senator JD Vance, is staunchly opposed to AI regulation. ‚ÄúRepublicans don't want to rush to overregulate this industry,‚Äù says Jacob Helberg, a tech executive and AI enthusiast who has been dubbed ‚ÄúSilicon Valley‚Äôs Trump whisperer.‚Äù But tech and cyber experts warn that eliminating the EO‚Äôs safety and security provisions would undermine the trustworthiness of AI models that are increasingly creeping into all aspects of American life, from transportation and medicine to employment and surveillance. The upcoming presidential election, in other words, could help determine whether AI becomes an unparalleled tool of productivity or an uncontrollable agent of chaos. Biden‚Äôs order addresses everything from using AI to improve veterans‚Äô health care to setting safeguards for AI‚Äôs use in drug discovery. But most of the political controversy over the EO stems from two provisions in the section dealing with digital security risks and real-world safety impacts. One provision requires owners of powerful AI models to report to the government about how they‚Äôre training the models and protecting them from tampering and theft, including by providing the results of ‚Äúred-team tests‚Äù designed to find vulnerabilities in AI systems by simulating attacks. The other provision directs the Commerce Department‚Äôs National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to produce guidance that helps companies develop AI models that are safe from cyberattacks and free of biases. Work on these projects is well underway. The government has proposed quarterly reporting requirements for AI developers, and NIST has released AI guidance documents on risk management, secure software development, synthetic content watermarking, and preventing model abuse, in addition to launching multiple initiatives to promote model testing. Supporters of these efforts say they‚Äôre essential to maintaining basic government oversight of the rapidly expanding AI industry and nudging developers toward better security. But to conservative critics, the reporting requirement is illegal government overreach that will crush AI innovation and expose developers‚Äô trade secrets, while the NIST guidance is a liberal ploy to infect AI with far-left notions about disinformation and bias that amount to censorship of conservative speech. At a rally in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, last December, Trump took aim at Biden‚Äôs EO after alleging without evidence that the Biden administration had already used AI for nefarious purposes. ‚ÄúWhen I‚Äôm reelected,‚Äù he said, ‚ÄúI will cancel Biden‚Äôs artificial intelligence executive order and ban the use of AI to censor the speech of American citizens on Day One.‚Äù Biden‚Äôs effort to collect information about how companies are developing, testing, and protecting their AI models sparked an uproar on Capitol Hill almost as soon as it debuted. Congressional Republicans seized on the fact that Biden justified the new requirement by invoking the 1950 Defense Production Act, a wartime measure that lets the government direct private-sector activities to ensure a reliable supply of goods and services. GOP lawmakers called Biden‚Äôs move inappropriate, illegal, and unnecessary. Conservatives have also blasted the reporting requirement as a burden on the private sector. The provision ‚Äúcould scare away would-be innovators and impede more ChatGPT-type breakthroughs,‚Äù Representative Nancy Mace said during a March hearing she chaired on ‚ÄúWhite House overreach on AI.‚Äù Helberg says a burdensome requirement would benefit established companies and hurt startups. He also says Silicon Valley critics fear the requirements ‚Äúare a stepping stone‚Äù to a licensing regime in which developers must receive government permission to test models. Steve DelBianco, the CEO of the conservative tech group NetChoice, says the requirement to report red-team test results amounts to de facto censorship, given that the government will be looking for problems like bias and disinformation. ‚ÄúI am completely worried about a left-of-center administration ‚Ä¶ whose red-teaming tests will cause AI to constrain what it generates for fear of triggering these concerns,‚Äù he says. Conservatives argue that any regulation that stifles AI innovation will cost the US dearly in the technology competition with China. ‚ÄúThey are so aggressive, and they have made dominating AI a core North Star of their strategy for how to fight and win wars,‚Äù Helberg says. ‚ÄúThe gap between our capabilities and the Chinese keeps shrinking with every passing year.‚Äù By including social harms in its AI security guidelines, NIST has outraged conservatives and set off another front in the culture war over content moderation and free speech. Republicans decry the NIST guidance as a form of backdoor government censorship. Senator Ted Cruz recently slammed what he called NIST‚Äôs ‚Äúwoke AI ‚Äòsafety‚Äô standards‚Äù for being part of a Biden administration ‚Äúplan to control speech‚Äù based on ‚Äúamorphous‚Äù social harms. NetChoice has warned NIST that it is exceeding its authority with quasi-regulatory guidelines that upset ‚Äúthe appropriate balance between transparency and free speech.‚Äù Many conservatives flatly dismiss the idea that AI can perpetuate social harms and should be designed not to do so. ‚ÄúThis is a solution in search of a problem that really doesn't exist,‚Äù Helberg says. ‚ÄúThere really hasn‚Äôt been massive evidence of issues in AI discrimination.‚Äù Studies and investigations have repeatedly shown that AI models contain biases that perpetuate discrimination, including in hiring, policing, and health care. Research suggests that people who encounter these biases may unconsciously adopt them. Conservatives worry more about AI companies‚Äô overcorrections to this problem than about the problem itself. ‚ÄúThere is a direct inverse correlation between the degree of wokeness in an AI and the AI's usefulness,‚Äù Helberg says, citing an early issue with Google‚Äôs generative AI platform. Republicans want NIST to focus on AI‚Äôs physical safety risks, including its ability to help terrorists build bioweapons (something Biden‚Äôs EO does address). If Trump wins, his appointees will likely deemphasize government research on AI‚Äôs social harms. Helberg complains that the ‚Äúenormous amount‚Äù of research on AI bias has dwarfed studies of ‚Äúgreater threats related to terrorism and biowarfare.‚Äù AI experts and lawmakers offer robust defenses of Biden‚Äôs AI safety agenda. These projects ‚Äúenable the United States to remain on the cutting edge‚Äù of AI development ‚Äúwhile protecting Americans from potential harms,‚Äù says Representative Ted Lieu, the Democratic cochair of the House‚Äôs AI task force. The reporting requirements are essential for alerting the government to potentially dangerous new capabilities in increasingly powerful AI models, says a US government official who works on AI issues. The official, who requested anonymity to speak freely, points to OpenAI‚Äôs admission about its latest model‚Äôs ‚Äúinconsistent refusal of requests to synthesize nerve agents.‚Äù The official says the reporting requirement isn‚Äôt overly burdensome. They argue that, unlike AI regulations in the European Union and China, Biden‚Äôs EO reflects ‚Äúa very broad, light-touch approach that continues to foster innovation.‚Äù Nick Reese, who served as the Department of Homeland Security‚Äôs first director of emerging technology from 2019 to 2023, rejects conservative claims that the reporting requirement will jeopardize companies‚Äô intellectual property. And he says it could actually benefit startups by encouraging them to develop ‚Äúmore computationally efficient,‚Äù less data-heavy AI models that fall under the reporting threshold. AI‚Äôs power makes government oversight imperative, says Ami Fields-Meyer, who helped draft Biden‚Äôs EO as a White House tech official. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre talking about companies that say they‚Äôre building the most powerful systems in the history of the world,‚Äù Fields-Meyer says. ‚ÄúThe government‚Äôs first obligation is to protect people. ‚ÄòTrust me, we‚Äôve got this‚Äô is not an especially compelling argument.‚Äù Experts praise NIST‚Äôs security guidance as a vital resource for building protections into new technology. They note that flawed AI models can produce serious social harms, including rental and lending discrimination and improper loss of government benefits. Trump‚Äôs own first-term AI order required federal AI systems to respect civil rights, something that will require research into social harms. The AI industry has largely welcomed Biden‚Äôs safety agenda. ‚ÄúWhat we're hearing is that it‚Äôs broadly useful to have this stuff spelled out,‚Äù the US official says. For new companies with small teams, ‚Äúit expands the capacity of their folks to address these concerns.‚Äù Rolling back Biden‚Äôs EO would send an alarming signal that ‚Äúthe US government is going to take a hands off approach to AI safety,‚Äù says Michael Daniel, a former presidential cyber adviser who now leads the Cyber Threat Alliance, an information sharing nonprofit. As for competition with China, the EO‚Äôs defenders say safety rules will actually help America prevail by ensuring that US AI models work better than their Chinese rivals and are protected from Beijing‚Äôs economic espionage. If Trump wins the White House next month, expect a sea change in how the government approaches AI safety. Republicans want to prevent AI harms by applying ‚Äúexisting tort and statutory laws‚Äù as opposed to enacting broad new restrictions on the technology, Helberg says, and they favor ‚Äúmuch greater focus on maximizing the opportunity afforded by AI, rather than overly focusing on risk mitigation.‚Äù That would likely spell doom for the reporting requirement and possibly some of the NIST guidance. The reporting requirement could also face legal challenges now that the Supreme Court has weakened the deference that courts used to give agencies in evaluating their regulations. And GOP pushback could even jeopardize NIST‚Äôs voluntary AI testing partnerships with leading companies. ‚ÄúWhat happens to those commitments in a new administration?‚Äù the US official asks. This polarization around AI has frustrated technologists who worry that Trump will undermine the quest for safer models. ‚ÄúAlongside the promises of AI are perils,‚Äù says Nicol Turner Lee, the director of the Brookings Institution‚Äôs Center for Technology Innovation, ‚Äúand it is vital that the next president continue to ensure the safety and security of these systems.‚Äù In your inbox: Upgrade your life with WIRED-tested gear A bitcoin mining dream turned into a nightmare The Big Interview: Marissa Mayer‚ÄîI am a software girl I made a wholesome OnlyFans to try to make ends meet Event: Join us for The Big Interview on December 3 in San Francisco More From WIRED Reviews and Guides ¬© 2024 Cond√© Nast. articles.author: James Fallows
articles.title: After the Election, California (Yes, That Hellscape) Will Keep Moving the World Forward No Matter What
articles.description: The state has been written off as a woke wasteland. But it's still inventing the future on a bunch of frontiers nobody's talking about. Even if Trump wins, it will remain a golden, global example.
articles.content: The first time Kamala Harris won more than a citywide political contest was in the summer of 2010. Jerry Brown had just decided not to run for another term as California‚Äôs attorney general and instead try for a third term in the governor‚Äôs office he‚Äôd occupied from 1975 to 1983. Harris, then San Francisco‚Äôs district attorney, decided to join the race to succeed him as AG, and she came out easily on top of a crowded Democratic field. Then, that fall, she barely nosed out her much better-known Republican opponent. It was the beginning of her career as a national figure. Back during that 2010 campaign, the newly-hired MSNBC host Lawrence O‚ÄôDonnell picked out Harris as the candidate Republicans should fear as ‚Äúthe next big Democratic star‚Äù and ‚Äúthe female Obama.‚Äù He ran a clip of her speech at the victory celebration after she won the primary for attorney general, which I happened to see. Harris, then in her mid-forties, looked and sounded surprisingly similar to the presidential candidate before us now, who turned 60 two weeks before Election Day. But she said something that has stayed with me. Kamala Harris holds a news conference in November 2010. ‚ÄúWe are the state that creates leadership for the rest of this country,‚Äù she told a cheering crowd of Californians, ‚Äúbased on our belief that we can be tough, and we can be smart‚Äîand all the time be dedicated to our history, while being empowered to know our destiny.‚Äù It was rhetoric that tapped deep into a shared awareness of California‚Äôs outsize role as a trendsetter and model-builder in American life. That is not the way Kamala Harris talks these days. Unless I‚Äôve missed it, she hasn‚Äôt discussed a California ‚Äúmodel‚Äù or its success stories, the way Republicans like Ron DeSantis and Greg Abbott do about their states, and as her running mate Tim Walz does about his own Minnesota. Her mentions of her time as district attorney of San Francisco and attorney general of the state are largely grim: sex predators, drug traffickers, domestic abusers safely prosecuted and sent away. Her California background seems to be something she is running despite, rather than running on. Of course that‚Äôs understandable. Harris‚Äô audience now is bigger than the one in 2010. And unlike DeSantis, Abbott, and Walz, she‚Äôs never been a governor, with a list of programmatic accomplishments to tick off. But it‚Äôs also an obvious tell about California‚Äôs changed place in the national and global mind. California has at many points been held up as an American paradise. Now it‚Äôs widely seen as closer to hell. Runaway housing prices, tax burdens, homelessness, congestion, fire, drought, flood. The best sides of tech innovation, and the worst of tech-bro greed and narcissism. These are the state‚Äôs hallmarks. This perception is particularly rampant among Republicans: Polls show that two-thirds of Republicans say this one US state has done more damage than good for the country, and that almost half of them don‚Äôt consider it ‚ÄúAmerican‚Äù at all. Beyond political party, fully half of adult Americans say in polls that California is in decline. As a recent headline put it shortly before Harris became the Democratic nominee, ‚ÄúCalifornia‚Äôs image will be a weapon‚Äù against her as a candidate. Damage and destruction from the 2024 Airport Fire in Lake Elsinore, California. Never mind that one in every eight Americans still lives in California‚Äîa population larger than 21 other US states combined‚Äîand that its economic output is bigger than any entire non-US country except China, Japan, or Germany, and that it‚Äôs the birthplace of an disproportionate share of the world‚Äôs most familiar and valuable brand names. The overwhelming sense is that the California miracle is over, its reservoirs of dynamism as tapped out as the Central Valley‚Äôs aquifers during recent years of drought. As a Californian who has spent most of his life in other parts of the United States, and as an American who has lived for more than a dozen years in other parts of the world, I‚Äôve often been struck by the ways declinist alarmism about my home state can feel like a displaced version of declinist alarmism about my home country as a whole. I‚Äôve been around long enough, and reported on enough of America‚Äôs recurring crises, to be familiar with this pattern. The United States, it seems, is always about to collapse or tear itself apart‚Äîbecause of war and turmoil in the 1960s, oil shock and stagflation in the 1970s, the Reagan recession and the Japanese menace in the 1980s, and on through all the other decades‚Äô predicaments, right up to its political divisions today. But just as each wave of declinist certainty sets in, the US somehow wriggles, or struggles, or innovates, or immigrates its way to a quicker rebound than any other country‚Äîas it has most recently in its economic growth since the pandemic. America‚Äôs long history has been a seesaw between facing dire problems (often of its own creation) and lurching toward solutions. And in this respect above all, what‚Äôs true of the United States is true of its most important state: It‚Äôs like the fulcrum of the seesaw. ‚ÄúCalifornia is America, but sooner,‚Äù the USC sociologist Manual Pastor has said. That goes for huge cultural and demographic shifts (California was the first mainland US state whose diverse population became ‚Äúmajority-minority,‚Äù back in the 1990s, a full generation ago) and for era-defining crises, self-inflicted and not. And most importantly, it also goes for solutions‚Äîthe kind that can redirect the momentum of American life, and life around the world, with a leverage no other state possesses. Just take the area of gasoline-powered transportation. After World War II, when American car culture was famously getting minted in Southern California, the state used a gas tax hike to build out one of the first modern freeway networks. In the ‚Äô50s, the US federal government borrowed that same model to construct the interstate highway system. Then, starting in the 1980s, California led the fight against leaded gasoline, eventually banning its sale in 1992, four years before the US as a whole did the same. In 2019, after Donald Trump‚Äôs administration rolled back emissions standards for cars, California struck a deal with the world‚Äôs leading carmakers, from Ford to Honda to VW and BMW‚Äîto make existing standards even tougher in the face of climate change. The size of the California market made this a de facto national standard (which the Biden administration later ratified). It would be one thing if this were just a history lesson. But the same kind of dynamic is playing out right now in a few crucial arenas that virtually no one beyond California is talking about. And I‚Äôm happy to report that the America taking shape on its Pacific coast is again inventing solutions far more rapidly than conventional wisdom has accounted for. I was bullish on these emerging transformations even before Kamala Harris became the Democratic nominee for president. If she wins, what she knows from California will presumably affect her approach to the country and the world. Her California-ness is one of the least-discussed but most important aspects of her, including the upbeat approach to today‚Äôs diversity and tomorrow‚Äôs opportunities that is such a contrast to Donald Trump. But if she doesn‚Äôt get that far, California is likely to chug along with all the more purpose, maintaining its nation-scale example of how else things can be done. Whoever guides national politics, California deserves new attention as the ‚Äúreinvention state‚Äù rather than a ‚Äúresistance state.‚Äù Even under Trump, there‚Äôs still a good chance that as California goes, so eventually goes the country, and eventually much of the world. Here are a few illustrations of where it‚Äôs headed. None of these is ‚Äúthe‚Äù solution to California‚Äôs many problems. But each of them illustrates the creative spirit from which solutions have always come. For starters, let‚Äôs return to the thread of transportation: By now, of course, the pioneering freeway system California built in the 20th century is a maxed-out, congested mess. And the state cannot build more freeways; where they‚Äôre needed, there‚Äôs no more room, and any that are built fill up as soon as they‚Äôre opened. Without new forms of transportation, the state will become increasingly paralyzed, and all its other problems will become worse. Which is why, back in 2008, California voters approved a nearly $10 billion initial bond issue to build a high-speed rail line eventually running some 500 miles from Los Angeles to San Francisco, through the Central Valley corridor. That was 16 years ago. If you‚Äôve heard anything at all about this project since then, it‚Äôs that it is a white elephant, a doomed relic, a cautionary lesson, and any other metaphor for failure you might choose. And yes, the complaint list is long. The project is way over budget (to the tune of $100 billion) and far behind its original schedule. Parts of the line were supposed to be up and running already. As it is, the first service isn‚Äôt projected to begin until 2030‚Äîand then only on the 171-mile segment from Merced, in the northern half of California‚Äôs Central Valley, to Bakersfield, on the southern end. This abbreviated initial route has been dubbed a ‚Äútrain to nowhere,‚Äù a stock insult that grates on people in the Central Valley but captures the frustration of people stuck in LA or Bay Area traffic. And given how the entire funding-hungry project has become an object of the culture wars, it is little wonder that for many, the project seems as remote and implausible as human settlements on Mars. When done, this will be among the very fastest mainline high-speed rail systems running anywhere on Earth‚Äîat 220 mph. But I‚Äôve been following the back-and-forth for more than a decade, and I‚Äôve started to see California‚Äôs high-speed rail project with a new clarity. In the aviation world, pilots are trained to recognize the ‚Äúpoint of no return,‚Äù when you‚Äôve gone so far that you‚Äôd only lose by going back. That‚Äôs where California is with high-speed rail. Consider the weight of a few recent facts: This summer the project received full ‚Äúenvironmental clearance‚Äù for the entire 463 miles from downtown LA to downtown San Francisco, with clearance for a further 31 miles from LA to Anaheim expected next year. Nearly all of the thousands of necessary land parcels have been secured. Construction in the Central Valley is much further along than most people realize: Some 12,000 people have long been at work there, and test trains should be running in three or four years. And what hasn‚Äôt sunk in is that, when done, this will be among the very fastest mainline high-speed rail systems running anywhere on Earth. (At 220 mph, it would beat the 200-mph range for European trains and the famed Shinkansen in Japan, or match the fastest stretches of the Beijing-to-Shanghai line in China.) Not only that, in a worldwide first, California‚Äôs system will use solar-generated electricity the entire way. Over the past decade, I‚Äôve visited Fresno, the biggest city along the initial route (population 545,000), about a dozen times. There and in surrounding areas you can see the rail taking shape month by month, mile by mile. You see the kind of gigantic, heavy-industrial construction projects I remember from living in China, when a new subway line seemed to be opening every month. You see earth movers bigger than school buses; concrete bridge-supports as long as airliners. The¬†Tule River Viaduct, shown under construction here, will carry some of the world's fastest trains. ‚ÄúIf you listen to California‚Äôs political class, the high-speed rail project sounds like a textbook boondoggle,‚Äù Yousef Baig wrote on the nonprofit news site CalMatters in January. ‚ÄúYet in communities across California‚Äôs farm belt, the discourse is refreshingly different. It‚Äôs a symbol of transformation for a region that‚Äôs already bursting with activity.‚Äù In part because of housing costs and traffic in the state‚Äôs biggest cities, communities in the Central Valley are the fastest-growing in the state; they are also some of the poorest, and the ones hardest hit by drought, particulate pollution, and climate change. These are the cities that will be the first to benefit from these futuristic new trains. The logic of opening a semirural section of the larger project as soon as possible‚Äîand not waiting for the state‚Äôs big population hubs before any trains start running‚Äîis pretty clear at this point. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm firmly convinced that the first time the first customer buys a first ticket for the first true high-speed rail trip on US soil, there will be no going back,‚Äù I heard Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg say this spring in Washington. ‚ÄúPeople will expect and demand it everywhere.‚Äù And lest Americans assume they will remain relegated to the kids‚Äô table of railway systems, the world truly is watching California. At an international gathering of high-speed rail officials this year, I heard officials from France, Italy, Germany, Austria, and even the home of the Shinkansen, Japan, speak eagerly and admiringly about what they hoped to see and learn from California‚Äôs system. ‚ÄúIt will be an incredible feat of civilization,‚Äù Ezra Silk, of the US High Speed Rail Coalition, told me. ‚ÄúIt is something we should celebrate as visionary.‚Äù Over the centuries, there‚Äôs a consistent pattern: Most big projects seem doomed before they‚Äôre done. Being over budget and behind schedule doesn‚Äôt prove that a huge infrastructure project will succeed. But it fits a familiar pattern. The Erie Canal. The Transcontinental Railroad. The Panama Canal. Those are just a few of the projects condemned as follies, boondoggles, or cesspools of corruption during the long years before their completion. The jewel of Sydney‚Äôs waterfront, its stunning Opera House, was widely ridiculed before its opening. Late, over budget, and the subject of bitter political and legal battles. Now it is hard to imagine the city without it. The state also doesn‚Äôt have an alternative. Not only are new freeways off the table, California will also never open another big airport. Through most of each day LAX and SFO are already landing as many planes-per-hour as they ever will, and San Diego and San Jose are nearly as busy. (I speak as a longtime pilot, and one who has studied peak-capacity issues at the airports.) And if the state tried to meet its transportation demands with new highways and air nodes, they‚Äôd be even more expensive than the trains, to say nothing of the climate effects. With high-speed rail, it's time to get all aboard. California‚Äôs new rail system is meant to set a model for addressing a fundamental ‚Äúhardware‚Äù problem for the state and much of America. What is the main ‚Äúsoftware‚Äù problem for modern America? Disconnection, loneliness, the withering-away of ‚Äúsocial capital,‚Äù the conversion of neighborhoods and real communities into mere lodging sites, whose residents have as weak a common bond as guests at a crowded hotel. The idea of an atomized America may be overstated‚Äîwhen my wife, Deb, and I spent several years reporting from smaller-town America through the 2010s, we found enough examples of reconnection and civic-mindedness to have made Alexis de Tocqueville proud. But polls, news accounts, and the hell of national politics all suggest that the problem is real. This is the challenge against which California may be creating its most original and ambitious model, and the one which, in contrast to high-speed rail, is already widely recognized as a success. It‚Äôs also the one you‚Äôre least likely to have seen covered in the news.The official name for this five-year-old project‚Äîa big, sprawling set of programs‚Äîis California Volunteers, or CalVolunteers for short. It is already bigger than the entire Peace Corps. Its programs have more applicants than spaces to fill and are limited only by how quickly the state can expand funding. And states across the country are embracing the model, with credit to its California origins. CalVolunteers falls under the purview of the state‚Äôs chief service officer, a new position in the governor‚Äôs cabinet that Gavin Newsom established early in his first term. Since the start of the program, its director has been Josh Fryday, who, like his friend Pete Buttigieg, is in his early forties and has similarities in background and role as ‚Äúchief explainer‚Äù and advocate for his programs. Fryday, from the small Bay Area town of Novato, graduated from UC Berkeley and its law school, then served as Navy JAG officer (and handled Guantanamo cases), then returned to Novato and was elected mayor. He was named to Newsom‚Äôs cabinet five years ago, at age 38. Long before Newsom‚Äôs arrival as governor, California‚Äîlike most states‚Äîhad a variety of public service and volunteer programs under the CalVolunteers label, many of them in partnership with the nationwide AmeriCorps system. Newsom‚Äôs innovation was to elevate them to cabinet level in a new department, with more funding, and to make them a personal trademark issue. (His wife, Jennifer Siebel Newsom, plays an active role as honorary chair of CalVolunteers.) I began to pay serious attention to this new program in the early stages of the pandemic, when it quickly organized ways around the state for volunteers to fill suddenly-emerging needs‚Äîfor instance, delivering food or medical supplies to people who were quarantined or unable to go out for it, or working in shelters or other crucial facilities that had lost their normal staff. I had happened to meet Fryday just before the pandemic lockdowns, when I was visiting my Southern California home town and he was launching a tree-planting program for student volunteers there. As the scope of CalVolunteers programs has expanded since then, my wife and I have been to visit more than a dozen CalVolunteers worksites. Teenagers training for new job skills in downtown Oakland and starting urban gardens in places that had been ‚Äúheat islands.‚Äù Young artists in a beaten-down part of Riverside helping to restore and beautify buildings. Grade-school children around the state learning how to plant and tend to trees. One of the best-known and largest programs is the California College Corps. It combines the main element of the original GI Bill‚Äînamely, rewarding service with educational benefits‚Äîwith a Peace Corps‚Äìlike ambition of fostering lifelong connections and a habit of looking for ways to serve. College Corps members commit to spending up to 450 hours on projects in their locality, tutoring and mentoring younger students, assisting in eldercare, working in food banks, doing environmental work, and so on. In return, they earn up to $10,000 toward their college expenses, plus other support from the partner schools themselves, all toward creating a ‚Äúdebt-free path‚Äù to a college education. Why $10,000? That‚Äôs a typical amount that recipients of Pell Grants, the main federal financial-aid program for college students, provide toward college costs, which often requires their taking out a loan or getting a part-time job. ‚ÄúTen thousand dollars is a very intentional number,‚Äù Fryday told me. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a way to have a debt-free path to an education. It makes the difference between working in a coffee shop to raise the money or serving the community.‚Äù A UC Irvine student, right, helps to package salad dressing as part of the College Corps program. The groups we met were ‚Äúmajority-minority‚Äù and in that way representative of the state‚Äôs population as a whole. Nearly all said they were the first in their families ever to go to college‚Äîand that the financial support and organizational structure of the College Corps had made that step more practical for them. In this third year of operations alone, the College Corps program received 10,000 applications for 3,000 available slots. Fryday‚Äôs goal is to have 10,000 graduates of the program by the end of its fourth year. And the number of ‚Äúpartner schools‚Äù has expanded from eight the first year to 44 now, ranging from the flagship UC Berkeley campus to small-town community colleges. ‚ÄúAbsolutely, our ambition is to export this,‚Äù Newsom told us. If there‚Äôs any program more popular than the College Corps, it would be the California Climate Action Corps, which in its latest cycle had six applicants for each of the 400 spaces it could offer. The people in the program improve waterways, plant native drought-resistant trees, restore marshlands, develop urban gardens, equip homes for fire-resistance. This year its members committed to planting 90,000 trees across the state‚Äîthe sort of long-term, public-benefit project you would associate with Franklin Roosevelt‚Äôs Civilian Conservation Corps. People who have read about the death of civic culture and the despair of screen-bound young Americans should see and meet some of these corps members. One example of hundreds: Chiena Ty, now 27, came to northern California at age 3 from the Philippines with her parents, who were from Manila and southern China. She graduated from California High School in San Ramon and went to college at UC Riverside. But she was attracted to the Climate Action Corps and the chance to serve back in the Bay Area, near her family. We met her at the White Pony Express food reclamation site in Contra Costa County, on the east side of the San Francisco Bay. Volunteers ranging from teenagers to retirees spend hours there sorting through expired food from major grocery chains or restaurants and repacking it for food banks, homeless shelters, assisted-living facilities, and other places of need‚Äîrather than sending it to a methane-producing landfill. Chiena spent part of each Climate Corps day on the sorting line and part making videos or giving public presentations about the climate consequences of wasted food. Last year, Deb and I asked the governor why he had put so much emphasis on CalVolunteers. ‚ÄúWhat are the two driving forces in life?‚Äù Newsom responded. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre inspiration and desperation, and in this case it was probably the latter.‚Äù The worsening polarization of public life made him wonder, he said: ‚ÄúHow do we reconcile our differences? How do we soften the edges and tone it down, since divorce is not an option for the country and we have to live together?‚ÄùNewsom said that one of his heroes was Sargent Shriver, the brother-in-law of John F. Kennedy, who is best known for leading the Peace Corps through its celebrated founding years in the 1960s. Shriver, like so many American civic and cultural leaders of that era, had been a combat veteran of World War II and was forever affected and inspired by the enforced sense of civic connection through the Depression, New Deal, and wartime years. ‚ÄúThe fact is, we no longer have these widely shared experiences,‚Äù Newsom told us, referring to Shriver‚Äôs time in uniform. In those days, nearly every family had some direct exposure to military service. Now comparatively few do. The point is not that the US needs more wars or more people in uniform but rather that it has dramatically fewer people routinely exposed to fellow citizens of different backgrounds. ‚ÄúEveryone longs for a sense of belonging, of meaning, of purpose and mission,‚Äù Newsom told us. He said that his goal was to make public service so attractive and available that it became ‚Äúuniversal‚Äù‚Äînot mandatory, as with a draft, but normal, natural, and expected, as part of growing up and even as part of growing older. And by ‚Äúuniversal,‚Äù Newsom also means people in other states. ‚ÄúAbsolutely, our ambition is to export this,‚Äù Newsom told us. In the summer of 2023, a few weeks after Chiena Ty guided us through the White Pony Express food reclamation site, she introduced another visitor for a look around another Bay Area conservation site: President Joe Biden. This summer, Biden swore in the inaugural class of the American Climate Corps, citing California as an example for the nation. Half a dozen governors have started projects similar to California‚Äôs climate corps and college corps in their states: Vermont, Minnesota, New Mexico, Colorado, Iowa, and more, with Republican-led Utah probably next on the list. Kathy Hochul, governor of New York, has explicitly credited CalVolunteers as an inspiration for her new statewide service program. In Maryland, Wes Moore, now in his first term as governor, has launched a new program for volunteer service. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think we would have been able to do it at this scale if not for the work of California, and other states,‚Äù he told me this summer. Moore is, like Fryday, a young veteran of the ‚Äúlong wars‚Äù-era military. He was in the 82nd Airborne in Afghanistan. ‚ÄúI believe that in a time of divisiveness and vitriol, service will save us,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúService is sticky. If we can serve together we can thrive.‚Äù This is California, so we‚Äôll end with a tech story. But it‚Äôs not about one of the famous companies that, for all their benefits, are always taking. Taking your particulars. Your preferences. Worst of all, your attention. Instead we‚Äôll talk about a company most people have not heard of. My parents were part of the great post‚ÄìWorld War II migration from the East Coast to California. I grew up with my three younger siblings in the small inland California town of Redlands. Its main business then was orange-growing. It was the kind of place Joan Didion wrote about as being repeatedly blasted by the unforgiving, furnace-hot Santa Ana winds. As our family kept growing, we kept moving to slightly bigger houses. Many weekends, we drove to the local nursery to buy seed, sod, and supplies. It was run by the Dutch-immigrant Dangermond family. My dad, a small-town doctor, gave some of them medical care. I didn‚Äôt know it at the time, but this was my introduction to one of the most powerful, least publicized tech tycoons of our era: Jack Dangermond, son of the immigrant nursery owners, and Laura Dangermond (a couple since they met in the early 1960s at Redlands High). After Jack‚Äôs time in college at Cal Poly Pomona and his time in graduate school at the University of Minnesota, followed by Harvard, the couple came back to Redlands. They started a company in an unlikely location, with an entirely novel mission, that has quietly provided the operating system for much of what you do each day. Esri, short for the original name of Environmental Systems Research Institute, is the most commercially successful entity worldwide in the field known as ‚ÄúGIS‚Äù‚Äîgeographic information system, which is both a precursor of Waze and Google Earth and a vastly more powerful version of either of them. If you have ever done anything involving location‚Äîhaving a package delivered, having a gas or electric or sewer line outside your house repaired, having an ambulance or fire truck or police squad routed to your neighborhood‚Äîyou have almost certainly relied on software developed by Esri. Almost every city and state government around the entire world has licensed and used the company‚Äôs GIS software for decades to understand where things are and how they interact. National governments use it for climate-forecasting, disease-tracking, regional-planning, and other purposes, including national defense. The United Nations relies on Esri software to track where drought or food supplies are becoming most critical, where the natural environment is most under attack, where global conservation efforts can make the most difference. When Tim Walz was announced as Kamala Harris‚Äô running mate, my reaction was ‚Äúwell, sure‚Äù rather than ‚Äúwho‚Äôs he?‚Äù‚Äîbecause I had heard him talk several times at Esri‚Äôs huge international User Conferences, about the way geographical information had guided his policies as governor of Minnesota. The annual subscription fees for Esri‚Äôs software can cost corporations and government agencies many thousands of dollars. The company, still privately owned, is very profitable. But from the start its founders have believed that technology gave their company a responsibility, as well as an opportunity. They‚Äôve made the software available free to K-12 schools around the world and have put more than $10 million into training and curriculum programs for the schools. TechSoup, a site that guides nonprofits to free or discounted technology, has featured Esri software. Jack Dangermond told me recently that, in part through TechSoup, the number of nonprofits using the company‚Äôs tools has doubled in the past year and is now more than 10,000. Environmental groups in Brazil and Colombia protecting forest reserves; public high school students in Los Angeles mapping patterns of health, pollution, and poverty in their communities; farmers in Africa mapping climate trends to choose their crops. More than 100 city, county, and regional jurisdictions across Southern California coordinate their transportation, land-use, and zoning programs with Esri software. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a unique, coordinated effort,‚Äù Damian Spangrud of Esri told me. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre zoning and you run up against the city boundary, you need to know what‚Äôs happening on the other side.‚Äù ‚ÄúA lot of the tech companies take data from their customers and monetize it themselves,‚Äù Jack Dangermond said. ‚ÄúWhat we do is ask our customers to share their data with other customers.‚Äù When I talked to Dangermond this month, he said that his users had created more than 73 million online maps from their own data, and more than 120 million counting those on their own local systems, with the total growing by thousands per day. The ‚Äúgeo-analysis‚Äù part of the GIS toolkit includes ways to combine weather data, animal records, flood or fire patterns, and other information to identify the places that really matter for species survival. The NatureServe nonprofit group in the US has created an Esri map of hot spots for ‚Äúbiodiversity importance.‚Äù The UN Biodiversity Lab has done it for lands and oceans around the world. And in California, Governor Newsom signed an executive order kicking off an initiative, involving Esri‚Äôs tools, for what he called ‚ÄúThirty by Thirty,‚Äù or 30x30. The idea was to recognize and protect the most biologically important 30 percent of the state‚Äôs lands and water, or roughly 6 million acres of land and half a million of coastal and inland waters. It‚Äôs an international goal, but California is setting an example in putting it to the test. ‚ÄúThis is the first place that has taken it seriously,‚Äù Jack Dangermond told me. He said that the International Union for Conservation of Nature, a leading worldwide sustainability organization, has ‚Äúmodeled conservation programs for the globe on what California has done.‚Äù California‚Äôs high-speed rail ambition is infrastructure in its most tangible sense. CalVolunteers addresses the civic infrastructure that distinguishes a society in collapse from one renewing itself. Esri‚Äôs software provides digital connective infrastructure between the two. In the 1950s and 1960s, Jerry Brown‚Äôs father, Pat Brown, was a two-term governor of the state. He took office intending to do a lot, to do it on a grand scale, to do it fast, and to do it for the long term. It seems incredible in retrospect, but within less than a decade, his plans helped build and open three entire new campuses of the University of California system: San Diego, Santa Cruz, and Irvine. I was a schoolchild through those years and took this pace of expansion in my home state for granted. Now we‚Äôd associate it only with overnight-infrastructure projects in China or maybe one of the Emirates. The story of America involves continued rediscovery of its potential. That is the story of the most American state as well. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd give anything to trade for America‚Äôs problems,‚Äù a senior Chinese bureaucrat told me in 2008, when I was living in Beijing and the United States seemed to be in free fall. America had emergencies; China, he explained, had more threatening long-term weaknesses‚Äîas has become clear in the years since then. As I write, America‚Äôs immediate political prospects are uncertain. But however this year‚Äôs election turns out‚Äîwith a president who was born in California, or with a California girding itself to show that it still represents the future‚Äîthe state demands attention for its many innovations, and not just its travails. ‚ÄúThe best minds in the world call California home because they‚Äôre liberated from the constraints of conformity and tradition,‚Äù Gavin Newsom said in his latest State of the State address. ‚ÄúCalifornia has figured out a way to make it work time and time again, decade after decade.‚ÄùIs this boosterism? Of course. But it is also an important constant in the American story, and California‚Äôs. I‚Äôd bet on it again. Let us know what you think about this article. articles.title: The Verge‚Äôs guide to the 2024 presidential election
articles.description: Vice President Kamala Harris is taking on former President Donald Trump. The election will determine the future of everything from electric cars to the entire legal system to to our democracy itself.
articles.content: A presidential campaign is an expression of ideology, often vocalized as a number of promises. Sometimes, those promises are made even when they‚Äôre outside the scope of what a president can enact. With Vice President Kamala Harris taking on former President Donald Trump, The Verge‚Äôs election guide attempts to cut through the noise of electioneering to identify the actual policies at stake. For the tech industry, many issues hang in the balance, including the regulatory power to govern AI, monopolies, and cryptocurrency. More broadly, this election will determine the future of electric vehicles and how the US approaches climate change.  But The Verge‚Äôs stake in this election is larger than just the tech issues. Every day, we walk our readers through the collective action problems that bedevil hardware, software, the internet, and all the other building blocks that make up our future. Once you start looking for collective action problems, you see them everywhere. What‚Äôs at stake in this election is whether it‚Äôs the government‚Äôs job to solve these problems ‚Äî or whether anyone should even bother trying.¬† An endorsement of democracy, solving problems, and Kamala Harris. Your vote matters. Here‚Äôs how it will change the future. The Verge‚Äôs guide to Project 2025. Conservative courts are strangling the functions of government. Another round of Trump judges will finish us. Trump has promised to roll back Biden‚Äôs EV policies on ‚Äòday one.‚Äô Here‚Äôs why the embattled SEC chair is a hot-button presidential issue. articles.author: Justine Calma
articles.title: Jeff Bezos says he‚Äôs a climate guy ‚Äî why is he kissing the ring?
articles.description: Jeff Bezos joined other tech moguls in congratulating Trump on his election victory. That doesn‚Äôt seem to jive with his ‚Äúpassion‚Äù for fighting climate change.
articles.content: By  Justine Calma, a senior science reporter covering energy and the environment with more than a decade of experience. She is also the host of Hell or High Water: When Disaster Hits Home, a podcast from Vox Media and Audible Originals. Jeff Bezos might just be the biggest climate philanthropist out there, which is what makes his swift embrace of Donald Trump as the next US president particularly cringeworthy. ‚ÄúWishing¬†@realDonaldTrump¬†all success in leading and uniting the America we all love,‚Äù Bezos posted on X, hours after Trump declared victory. The Amazon founder and chair launched his Bezos Earth Fund in 2020, committing $10 billion to funding action on climate change. The fund‚Äôs website describes it as ‚Äúthe largest philanthropic commitment ever to fight climate change and protect nature.‚Äù  ‚ÄúEarth is the one thing we all have in common ‚Äî let‚Äôs protect it, together,‚Äù Bezos wrote on Instagram when he announced the fund. He stepped down from his post as Amazon CEO in 2021 to focus on the fund, The Washington Post, and his other ‚Äúpassions.‚Äù (Bezos reportedly killed The Washington Post‚Äôs planned endorsement of Kamala Harris.) President-elect Trump, meanwhile, says rising sea levels ‚Äî¬†which make storms and flooding more dangerous thanks to climate change ‚Äî simply mean ‚Äúyou‚Äôll have more ocean front property.‚Äù On the campaign trail, he disparaged solutions like renewable energy ‚Äî pushing misinformation like the myth that offshore wind farms are killing whales along US shorelines. He consistently downplays the risks posed by climate change, even as the US reels from disasters like Hurricane Helene that were supercharged by greenhouse gas emissions. During his first term in office, Trump rolled back more than 100 environmental regulations, placed¬†fossil fuel lobbyists¬†in charge¬†of the Environmental Protection Agency, and briefly pulled the US out of the international Paris agreement to stop climate change.  While the US dropped the ball on climate action at the federal level, local leaders and even the private sector attempted to fill in the gaps. During the last couple of years of Trump‚Äôs first term, a wave of big tech companies made commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions ‚Äî¬†ostensibly in line with what‚Äôs needed to reach Paris climate agreement goals.  One of the early companies to do so was Amazon, which set a goal in 2019 of reaching net zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2040. Fast-forward to 2023, and the company still produced¬†34 percent more carbon pollution than it did when it made its first climate pledge ‚Äî although its emissions have started to come back down slightly, according to Amazon‚Äôs latest sustainability report. Since its inception, the Bezos Earth Fund has given $2 billion in grants to a wide array of projects ‚Äî from protecting forests to tracking planet-heating methane pollution by satellite. To be sure, the fund has faced some criticism over the years about Amazon‚Äôs own pollution and over how effective and equitable some of the programs it supports have been. Over time, though, the fund has started to funnel more money into grassroots groups working to ensure that there are more diverse voices being heard when it comes to finding solutions. (The Bezos Earth Fund didn‚Äôt immediately respond to requests for comment from The Verge.) Under another Trump presidency, locally led climate action and philanthropy become even more crucial again. Upon stepping back into office, Trump is expected to introduce a landslide of new policies that would slow the transition to cleaner energy needed to keep climate disasters from growing much worse.  Notably, he said he‚Äôd rescind unspent funds from the 2022 Inflation Reduction Act that set aside $369 billion for energy efficiency initiatives and the¬†domestic manufacturing¬†of electric vehicles and clean energy technologies. The Inflation Reduction Act alone is projected to slash greenhouse gas emissions by roughly 40 percent from 2005 levels by the end of the decade ‚Äî bringing the US close to reaching goals President Joe Biden set upon recommitting the US to the Paris climate agreement.  Another Trump presidency, on the other hand, would likely increase US greenhouse gas emissions by 4 billion metric tons compared to Biden‚Äôs plans, according to a Carbon Brief analysis published before Harris became the Democratic candidate. Trump has also said that he‚Äôd take the US out of the Paris accord again.  Bezos certainly isn‚Äôt the only tech mogul to kiss the ring since Trump‚Äôs win at the polls this week. Elon Musk has been one of Trump‚Äôs most influential hype men. Apple‚Äôs Tim Cook, Meta‚Äôs Mark Zuckerberg, Google‚Äôs Sundar Pichai, and Microsoft‚Äôs Satya Nadella have all extended their congratulations, to name a few. The president-elect has responded well to flattery in the past, after all ‚Äî offering Musk his own ‚Äúefficiency‚Äù task force to run. And Trump frequently threatens his critics with retribution. All the bromance could really just be a strategic play on the part of Bezos and other billionaires to protect their bottom lines. But that list represents a lot of money and power that could either help keep climate goals alive or fall in line behind a president who told Musk in August that ‚Äúthe biggest threat is nuclear warming ‚Ä¶ To me, the biggest problem is not climate change.‚Äù  / Sign up for Verge Deals to get deals on products we've tested sent to your inbox weekly. articles.author: Lauren Feiner
articles.title: FCC chair rejects Trump‚Äôs call to revoke CBS license over Harris interview edit
articles.description: The Federal Communications Commission rejected Trump‚Äôs call to revoke CBS‚Äôs broadcast license due to sharing two edits of Harris‚Äô response to an interview question.
articles.content: By  Lauren Feiner, a senior policy reporter at The Verge, covering the intersection of Silicon Valley and Capitol Hill. She spent 5 years covering tech policy at CNBC, writing about antitrust, privacy, and content moderation reform. Federal Communications Commission chair Jessica Rosenworcel rejected former President Donald Trump‚Äôs call to revoke CBS‚Äôs broadcast license on Thursday, calling it a familiar threat that ‚Äúshould not be ignored.‚Äù Trump called for the license to be revoked after the network shared two different edits of a recent 60 Minutes interview with Vice President Kamala Harris. Trump criticized the interview as ‚Äúa giant Fake News Scam‚Äù in a Truth Social post on Thursday and claimed the network replaced her answer on a question about Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu ‚Äúin order to save her or, at least, make her look better.‚Äù  Trump shared a compilation of two versions of Harris‚Äô answer to the question, with one labeled ‚Äúactual answer‚Äù and the other labeled ‚Äúedited answer,‚Äù even though both were shared by CBS. One was shared by the 60 Minutes X account in a teaser, while the other depicts a version that appeared in CBS‚Äôs transcript of the full interview. CBS did not immediately respond to The Verge‚Äôs request for comment. ‚ÄúTAKE AWAY THE CBS LICENSE,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúElection Interference.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhile repeated attacks against broadcast stations by the former President may now be familiar, these threats against free speech are serious and should not be ignored,‚Äù Rosenworcel said in a statement. ‚ÄúAs I‚Äôve said before, the First Amendment is a cornerstone of our democracy. The FCC does not and will not revoke licenses for broadcast stations simply because a political candidate disagrees with or dislikes content or coverage.‚Äù If this sounds familiar, it‚Äôs because Rosenworcel rejected a similar call from Trump in September. That time, Trump objected to ABC‚Äôs moderation and fact-checking of the presidential debate.  / Sign up for Verge Deals to get deals on products we've tested sent to your inbox weekly. articles.author: Justine Calma
articles.title: Amazon says it ditched plastic air pillows
articles.description: Amazon says it has gotten rid of plastic air pillows at warehouses around the world.
articles.content: By  Justine Calma, a senior science reporter covering energy and the environment with more than a decade of experience. She is also the host of Hell or High Water: When Disaster Hits Home, a podcast from Vox Media and Audible Originals. Amazon says that it has gotten rid of plastic air pillows at its warehouses. ‚ÄúAs of October 2024, we‚Äôve removed all plastic air pillows from our delivery packaging used at our global fulfillment centers,‚Äù the e-commerce giant said in an October 9th blog post.  It‚Äôs a welcome change following years of pressure from environmental groups to stop plastic pollution flooding into oceans. The company is still working to reduce the use of single-use plastics more broadly in its packaging.  ‚ÄúFantastic news for the world‚Äôs oceans‚Äù ‚ÄúThe fact that the world‚Äôs largest e-commerce company has made plastic air pillows history globally is fantastic news for the world‚Äôs oceans,‚Äù Matt Littlejohn, senior vice president of strategic initiatives at the nonprofit Oceana, said in a statement in response to Amazon‚Äôs announcement. The most prolific type of¬†plastic litter near coastlines is plastic film ‚Äî a material that makes up those once ubiquitous air pillows, according to Oceana. That film also happens to be the ‚Äúdeadliest‚Äù type of plastic pollution for large mammals like whales and dolphins that might ingest it, Oceana says. Amazon‚Äôs announcement comes after it pledged in June to get rid of plastic air pillows in North America by the end of the year. The company swapped out plastic air pillows and single-use delivery bags for paper and cardboard alternatives in Europe in 2022. It also ditched plastic film packaging at its facilities in India in 2020.  The US is Amazon‚Äôs largest market, and the company hasn‚Äôt managed to fully eliminate plastic packaging in North America just yet. It says it plans to reduce the amount of deliveries containing ‚ÄúAmazon-added plastic delivery packaging‚Äù in North America to just one-third of shipments by December, down from two-thirds in December 2023.  / Sign up for Verge Deals to get deals on products we've tested sent to your inbox weekly.
